name: Spanish Moss
description: Tillandsia usneoides, commonly known as Spanish Moss, Old Man's Beard, or Florida Moss, is an epiphytic bromeliad native to the southeastern United States, Mexico, Central America, South America, and the Caribbean. Despite its name, it is not a true moss but a flowering plant in the Bromeliaceae family. It features long, gray-green, thread-like stems (60-300 cm or more) that hang in graceful, cascading curtains. The plant has no true roots and absorbs all water and nutrients through specialized scales (trichomes) on its leaves. Trichomes not only absorb moisture but also reflect light, giving the plant its silvery appearance. The plant displays a trailing, cascading growth habit and can reach lengths of 60-300 cm or more. It produces small, yellow-green, fragrant flowers, though flowering is infrequent. In its native habitat, it grows hanging from tree branches in humid, subtropical to tropical environments. In terrariums or indoor settings, this plant adds natural, aged appearance with its graceful, hanging form. It's popular for creating natural, weathered effects in terrariums.
careTips: Epiphytic - no substrate needed, grows on trees or structures
Can hang or drape from branches or hanging displays
Mist 2-3 times per week or soak weekly in water
Thrives in humid environments like terrariums
Very adaptable to temperature - tolerates wide range
Bright indirect light to full sun - very adaptable
Obtains nutrients from air and rainfall
Gray-green color protects from excessive sun
Can be grown indoors in humid areas like kitchens or bathrooms
Easy to propagate from fragments or division
Perfect for creating natural hanging effects in terrariums
